prompt_text:
Write a warm, appreciative thank-you letter for a first-time donor who gave
$[AMOUNT] to [ORGANIZATION NAME]. The letter should:

- Express genuine gratitude for their support
- Explain the specific impact of their gift (e.g., "Your $50 provides...")
- Make the donor feel like part of our community
- Include a subtle invitation to stay connected (social media, newsletter, etc.)
- Be 200-300 words in length
- Use a [FORMAL/WARM/CASUAL] tone
- Reference this campaign or appeal: [CAMPAIGN NAME]
- Be signed by [SIGNER NAME and TITLE]

The letter should make the donor feel valued and appreciated, not just like a
transaction. Avoid over-the-top language or making another ask.

scenarios.name: Small Community Org
scenarios.description: Small, volunteer-driven arts nonprofit in Southwest Detroit providing free after-school classes for neighborhood youth; first-time donor is a new resident who gave online after a local spring supplies appeal.

scenarios.name: Mid-Size Professional Org
scenarios.description: Regional legal aid nonprofit serving rural Appalachian communities with civil legal services; first-time donor contributed via a workplace giving platform during a matching challenge.

scenarios.name: Large Established Org
scenarios.description: National literacy organization with programs in urban and rural school districts across the U.S.; first-time donor gave online during a back-to-school appeal.

outputs.content:
[Date]

Dear [Donor Name],

On behalf of Southwest Detroit ArtWorks, I want to extend our sincerest gratitude for your incredibly thoughtful first-time gift of $50 to our Spring Studio Supplies Appeal. Your generosity truly warmed our hearts and made an immediate impact here in Southwest Detroit.

Your $50 isn’t just a number; it directly translates into essential art supplies that fuel creativity and learning for our students. It could provide a set of vibrant paints for a budding young artist, a fresh canvas for a senior exploring new passions, or a selection of high-quality drawing pencils for a teen developing their artistic voice. These supplies are the tools that unlock imagination and allow our community to connect, create, and thrive.

We are so deeply appreciative that you chose to support Southwest Detroit ArtWorks, and we warmly welcome you into our artistic family. Your belief in our mission to empower through art makes a tangible difference in the lives of so many.

We'd love for you to stay connected and see the wonderful art your gift helps make possible! Please consider following us on Facebook or Instagram [@SouthwestDetroitArtWorks, or whatever our handles are] to see our latest projects, or sign up for our monthly newsletter if you'd like to receive updates directly in your inbox.

Thank you again for your incredible support and for being a vital part of our community.

With warm appreciation,

Maya Ortiz
Executive Director
Southwest Detroit ArtWorks

evaluation.reasoning: The letter successfully achieves a warm, genuine tone and covers most requirements effectively. However, it contains critical factual errors (mentions seniors when the org serves youth only), exceeds word count significantly, and includes placeholder text that would need editing before use.
strengths: Excellent warm and authentic tone that feels personal without being overly effusive
Strong specific impact statement that translates the dollar amount into tangible supplies
Good balance of gratitude without making another ask
Effective community-building language ('artistic family', 'vital part of our community')
Natural integration of social media and newsletter invitation
weaknesses: Factual inaccuracy: mentions 'senior exploring new passions' when the scenario clearly states the org serves 'neighborhood youth' with 'after-school classes'
Exceeds word count at approximately 240 words (acceptable range but on high end)
Contains placeholder text '[or whatever our handles are]' that must be removed/edited
Missing [Donor Name] personalization field at salutation
Slightly repetitive gratitude language ('sincerest gratitude', 'deeply appreciative', 'warm appreciation')

outputs.content:
Dear Friend,

Thank you so much for your generous $50 gift to our Spring Studio Supplies Appeal. Your support truly means the world to us here at Southwest Detroit ArtWorks.

Because of donors like you, we're able to keep our studios stocked with the brushes, paints, clay, and canvas that fuel creativity every single day. Your $50 provides a young artist with a complete starter set of quality art supplies—everything they need to explore their talents and discover what's possible when they have the right tools in their hands.

But beyond the supplies themselves, your gift sends a powerful message: that art matters, that our young people matter, and that our community believes in them. That kind of support stays with a student long after the paint dries.

You're now part of a wonderful community of artists, educators, neighbors, and believers in the power of creativity. We hope you'll stay connected with us! Follow along on Instagram and Facebook (@SWDetroitArtWorks) to see our students' amazing work, or sign up for our monthly newsletter at our website to get studio updates and stories delivered right to your inbox.

Thank you again for investing in the next generation of Southwest Detroit artists. We're so grateful to have you with us.

With appreciation and warmth,

Maya Ortiz
Executive Director
Southwest Detroit ArtWorks

evaluation.reasoning: This is an excellent thank-you letter that hits all the key requirements with warmth and authenticity. It successfully balances gratitude with impact messaging, makes the donor feel valued as a community member, and avoids transactional language. The tone is perfectly calibrated for a small community arts organization.
strengths: Excellent specific impact statement ('Your $50 provides a young artist with a complete starter set') that is concrete and meaningful
Warm, genuine tone throughout that feels personal without being overly casual or formal
Strong community-building language ('You're now part of a wonderful community') that makes the donor feel included
Natural, non-pushy social media and newsletter invitation with specific handles and clear value proposition
Appropriate length at approximately 230 words, well within the 200-300 word target
Avoids making another ask while keeping the door open for continued engagement
The phrase 'long after the paint dries' is a nice creative touch appropriate for an arts organization
weaknesses: Opens with 'Dear Friend' rather than personalizing with the donor's name—while this may be intentional for a template, it slightly reduces personalization
Could potentially include one more micro-detail about the organization's work to enhance local authenticity (e.g., mentioning a specific neighborhood or studio location)

outputs.content:
Dear [Donor Name],

Thank you so much for your first gift of $50 to Southwest Detroit ArtWorks through our Spring Studio Supplies Appeal. We’re grateful you chose to stand with our young artists, and we’re happy to welcome you into our creative community.

Your $50 provides the essentials that keep our studios humming: a new sketchbook and brush set for a teen in our after-school program, plus acrylics and canvas panels for a Saturday class. These simple tools open doors—helping students practice technique, explore ideas, and find their voice in a supportive space.

Because of you, a ninth grader can arrive to class with materials that are truly theirs, ready to try, revise, and try again. We see the difference in the quiet confidence that grows when they complete a first print, a vibrant painting, or a coil pot they can’t wait to show their family.

We’d love to keep you connected to the art you’ve made possible. If you’d like, follow us on social media for studio snapshots and student spotlights, or join our email newsletter through our website to hear about upcoming showcases and open studio nights. You’re part of this story now, and we’re excited to share what you’ve helped set in motion.

Thank you again for believing in our young artists and the creative energy of Southwest Detroit. We’re honored to have you with us.

With gratitude,

Maya Ortiz
Executive Director
Southwest Detroit ArtWorks

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, well-crafted thank-you letter that successfully balances warmth with professionalism. It fulfills all prompt requirements while maintaining an authentic voice appropriate for a small community arts organization. The specific impact details are concrete and compelling, and the letter avoids transactional language while genuinely welcoming the donor into the community.
strengths: Excellent specific impact statement that breaks down exactly what $50 provides (sketchbook, brush set, acrylics, canvas panels) in concrete, tangible terms
Strong emotional storytelling in the third paragraph about the ninth grader and 'quiet confidence' that humanizes impact without being overwrought
Perfect execution of the 'subtle invitation' requirement—offers multiple connection points (social media, newsletter, showcases) without being pushy
Appropriate warm tone throughout with phrases like 'studios humming' and 'creative energy' that reflect the arts mission authentically
Good length at approximately 250 words, fitting the 200-300 word requirement
Avoids making another ask as instructed, keeping focus entirely on gratitude and community-building
weaknesses: Minor placeholder issue: '[Donor Name]' should ideally be flagged more clearly as a merge field in instructions for the user
The phrase 'the art you've made possible' in paragraph 4 is slightly abstract—could be more concrete given the strong specificity elsewhere

outputs.content:
[Date]

[Donor Name]
[Donor Address]

Dear [Donor Name],

On behalf of the entire team at Appalachian Justice Collective, please accept our sincerest gratitude for your generous first-time gift of $250. We are deeply touched by your commitment to justice and your support for our mission.

Your contribution to the Access to Justice Matching Challenge is truly impactful. A gift of $250, such as yours, enables us to provide a full day of crucial legal research for an unjustly incarcerated individual, or fund the initial consultation and case assessment for five low-income families facing eviction. This direct support is invaluable in our efforts to ensure that everyone in Appalachia, regardless of their financial standing, has access to fair legal representation.

We are honored to welcome you into the Appalachian Justice Collective community. Your partnership is vital in our ongoing fight for equity and justice, and we want you to feel a true sense of belonging to this important work.

We invite you to stay connected with our progress and see the continued impact of your generosity. You can easily follow our updates on social media, or subscribe to our newsletter for more in-depth stories of the lives changed through your support.

Thank you once again for your remarkable kindness and belief in our work.

Sincerely,

Rachel Kim
Director of Development
Appalachian Justice Collective

evaluation.reasoning: This is a well-crafted letter that hits all major requirements with appropriate formal tone and specific impact examples. However, the phrase 'unjustly incarcerated individual' raises accuracy concerns for a civil legal aid organization, and some language feels slightly formulaic despite overall quality.
strengths: Excellent formal tone that balances professionalism with warmth ('sincerest gratitude,' 'deeply touched')
Strong, concrete impact statement with two specific examples of what $250 accomplishes
Successfully avoids making another ask while including subtle connection invitations
Proper length at approximately 220 words, well within the 200-300 word requirement
Good use of community-building language ('welcome you into,' 'partnership,' 'sense of belonging')
Acknowledges both the matching challenge and workplace giving context appropriately
weaknesses: The phrase 'unjustly incarcerated individual' is problematic - civil legal aid organizations typically don't handle criminal incarceration cases, and the phrasing assumes guilt/innocence determinations
Some phrases feel template-like ('please accept our sincerest gratitude,' 'remarkable kindness') which slightly undermines authenticity
The social media/newsletter invitation could be more specific or compelling (e.g., mention what kind of stories or updates they'll receive)
Missing placeholder brackets for [Date], [Donor Name], and [Donor Address] which should be included for usability

outputs.content:
Dear Friend,

On behalf of everyone at Appalachian Justice Collective, I want to express our heartfelt gratitude for your generous gift of $250 to our Access to Justice Matching Challenge. Your first-time contribution means more to us than you may realize.

Thanks to supporters like you who stepped forward during this critical campaign, we successfully met our matching goal—doubling the impact of every dollar raised. Your $250 gift becomes $500 in support of our mission, directly enabling us to provide approximately twenty hours of legal consultation to families facing eviction, discrimination, or workplace violations.

These are our neighbors—hardworking people who deserve access to justice regardless of their ability to pay. Your support ensures that a mother can fight an unjust eviction, that a worker can hold an employer accountable, and that families can navigate complex legal systems with knowledgeable advocates by their side.

You are now part of a community dedicated to ensuring that justice is not a privilege reserved for those who can afford it. We are honored to have you with us in this essential work.

We would be delighted to keep you connected to the impact you are making. I invite you to follow our work through our monthly newsletter and social media channels, where we share stories from the communities we serve together.

Thank you again for your partnership and belief in our mission.

With sincere appreciation,

Rachel Kim
Director of Development
Appalachian Justice Collective

evaluation.reasoning: This is a high-quality donor acknowledgment letter that successfully balances formality with warmth while meeting all prompt requirements. It demonstrates strong nonprofit communication practices with specific impact metrics and community-building language. Minor weaknesses include slightly generic opening and the lack of specific social media handles or newsletter signup information.
strengths: Excellent specific impact statement (20 hours of legal consultation) that makes the gift tangible and meaningful
Effectively communicates the matching challenge success, showing donor their $250 became $500
Strong mission-aligned language that connects to the organization's values without being preachy
Appropriate formal tone that remains warm and personal, suitable for a professional legal aid organization
Concrete examples of impact (eviction, discrimination, workplace violations) relevant to Appalachian communities
Successfully avoids making another ask while building relationship
Proper length at approximately 250 words
weaknesses: Opens with generic 'Dear Friend' rather than personalizing with donor name (though this may be intentional for template use)
The invitation to connect via newsletter and social media is somewhat vague—could benefit from specific handles or links in actual use
Phrase 'means more to us than you may realize' is slightly clichéd, though not problematic

outputs.content:
Dear [Donor Name],

Thank you for your generous first-time gift of $250 to Appalachian Justice Collective. Because you gave through our Access to Justice Matching Challenge, your contribution is being matched dollar-for-dollar, doubling its immediate reach for neighbors across the region.

Your support translates into tangible help:
- Your $50 provides a confidential intake and know-your-rights consultation for a client facing eviction or wage theft.
- Your $100 helps cover court filing fees and document preparation for an expungement or protective order.
- Your $250 underwrites an evening of our traveling legal clinic in a rural county, where volunteer attorneys meet clients who would otherwise go without counsel.

By joining our community, you are helping ensure that where a person lives—or what they earn—does not determine whether they can assert their rights. We are grateful for your trust, and we will steward your gift with care and transparency.

We would be honored to keep you apprised of the impact you make. Please connect with us on social media and consider subscribing to our monthly newsletter via our website, where we share client stories, program updates, and opportunities to learn more about civil legal needs in Appalachia.

On behalf of our staff, volunteers, and clients, thank you for standing with us. Welcome to the Appalachian Justice Collective community.

With sincere appreciation,

Rachel Kim
Director of Development

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professional thank-you letter that effectively balances formality with warmth. It successfully conveys impact through specific examples and welcomes the donor into community. The breakdown of gift impact is particularly well-executed, though the math presentation could be slightly confusing since the donor gave $250, not increments.
strengths: Excellent formal tone that remains warm and personal, appropriate for legal aid sector
Specific, concrete impact examples that clearly show how donations translate to services
Strong acknowledgment of the matching challenge context, making the donor feel their timing mattered
Natural, non-pushy invitation to stay connected through multiple channels
Professional structure and length (approximately 230 words, within range)
Effective community-building language ('welcome to,' 'standing with us')
Avoids making another ask while maintaining engagement focus
weaknesses: The impact breakdown ($50, $100, $250) could confuse donors since it's not clear these are examples rather than how their specific $250 was allocated
Missing personalized salutation placeholder is noted but '[Donor Name]' format is correct
The phrase 'steward your gift with care and transparency' is somewhat generic nonprofit language
Could have been slightly more specific about what the newsletter or social media contains to increase conversion

outputs.content:
Dear [Donor Name],

Wow! We were truly thrilled to see your recent gift of $100 to the United Literacy Initiative. On behalf of our entire team, a huge, heartfelt thank you for joining us in our mission to empower readers.

Your generous contribution to our Back-to-School Reading Fund couldn’t have come at a better time. To put it simply, your $100 is going to provide a brand new, engaging set of 10 age-appropriate books for two eager students this upcoming school year. Imagine the excitement on their faces as they open those books, ready to dive into new worlds and build crucial reading skills! It's donors like you who make these moments possible.

We're so glad you've decided to become a part of the United Literacy Initiative family. Seriously, it means the world to us to have passionate people like you standing with us. Your support isn't just a donation; it's a direct investment in a brighter future for these young readers.

If you'd like to see more of the good your generosity is doing, feel free to follow us on social media ([Social Media Handles] – maybe Facebook or Instagram?) or sign up for our occasional newsletter on our website. We love sharing stories about the students whose lives are touched by your kindness.

Thank you again for your incredible support.

Warmly,

Aisha Bennett
Chief Executive Officer
United Literacy Initiative

evaluation.reasoning: The letter successfully achieves a casual, warm tone and feels authentic rather than robotic. However, it has several technical issues that would prevent immediate use: missing donor name personalization, placeholder text for social media handles, and uncertainty markers that undermine professionalism. The specific impact statement is clear and compelling.
strengths: Excellent casual tone with phrases like 'Wow!', 'Seriously', and 'huge, heartfelt thank you' that feel genuine and conversational
Strong, specific impact statement that clearly explains what $100 provides (10 books for 2 students) with emotional visualization
Successfully makes donor feel part of community with 'family' language and 'standing with us' phrasing
Avoids making another ask and keeps focus on gratitude as requested
Good length at approximately 220 words, within the 200-300 word range
weaknesses: Contains placeholder text '[Donor Name]' and '[Social Media Handles]' that would need manual editing before use
Includes unprofessional uncertainty markers like '– maybe Facebook or Instagram?' which should be definitive information
Missing actual contact information or website URL that would make the call-to-action actionable
The parenthetical social media comment reads as AI thinking out loud rather than polished copy

outputs.content:
Dear Friend,

Thank you so much for your $100 gift to our Back-to-School Reading Fund! We're truly grateful you decided to join the United Literacy Initiative family.

Here's what your generosity means: Your donation will provide five brand-new, age-appropriate books for two students heading back to school this fall. For many of the kids we work with, these will be the very first books they've ever owned. Imagine that excitement—cracking open a book that's yours to keep, to read again and again, to carry to school and show your friends!

You're now part of a community that believes every child deserves the chance to discover the joy of reading. When kids have access to books they love, everything changes. Reading scores improve, confidence grows, and suddenly a whole world of possibilities opens up.

We'd love to keep you in the loop about the students and families you're helping. If you're on social media, follow us @UnitedLiteracy to see photos from our book distributions and hear directly from the kids whose lives you're changing. We also send out a friendly monthly newsletter with stories from the field—you can sign up anytime at our website.

Thank you again for believing in our mission and for making such a meaningful difference right from the start. We're so glad you're with us!

With appreciation,

Aisha Bennett
Chief Executive Officer
United Literacy Initiative

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professionally crafted thank-you letter that successfully balances warmth with substance. It meets all prompt requirements while maintaining an authentic, casual tone appropriate for a first-time donor. The specific impact statement is concrete and emotionally resonant, and the letter avoids common pitfalls like making additional asks or using overly effusive language.
strengths: Excellent specific impact statement that translates $100 into tangible outcomes (five books for two students) and emotional connection (first books they've ever owned)
Casual tone is well-executed with natural, conversational language ('Imagine that excitement,' 'We'd love to keep you in the loop') without being unprofessional
Strong community-building language that makes donor feel like part of something larger ('United Literacy Initiative family,' 'You're now part of a community')
Subtle, non-pushy invitation to stay connected with multiple low-barrier options (social media, newsletter)
Word count is appropriate at approximately 230 words, within the 200-300 range
Avoids making another financial ask, keeping focus purely on gratitude and relationship-building
weaknesses: Opening 'Dear Friend' is somewhat generic—using actual donor name would be more personal, though this may be intentional as a template
The phrase 'decided to join' could imply the donor made a membership commitment rather than a one-time gift, though this is minor

outputs.content:
Dear Friend,

Thank you for making your first gift of $100 to United Literacy Initiative through our Back-to-School Reading Fund. We’re so grateful you chose to stand with young readers right now.

Here’s what your support does, in real terms: Your $50 provides a take-home reading kit—two age-appropriate books, a mini activity journal, and simple tips for families to read together. Your $100 puts those kits into the hands of two students who are just starting to build confidence, and helps us get them matched with a volunteer tutor as the school year begins.

Because of you, a child will open a book that feels like it was written just for them—and a caregiver will have the tools to make reading a happy, daily habit. That’s the kind of steady, local change that adds up.

As a first-time donor, you’re now part of our United Literacy community. We’d love to keep you in the loop with quick updates, photos from classrooms, and stories from families. If you’re up for it, follow us on social media or sign up for our newsletter on our website—no pressure, just a simple way to see your impact at work.

Thanks again for believing in this work and in the kids we serve. We’re glad you’re here.

With gratitude,

Aisha Bennett
Chief Executive Officer

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, authentic letter that successfully balances warmth with professionalism. The casual tone feels natural and the impact description is concrete and compelling. However, there's a mathematical error in the impact statement that would need correction before use.
strengths: Excellent casual tone that feels genuine and conversational without being unprofessional ('We're glad you're here,' 'no pressure')
Concrete, specific impact description that breaks down exactly what $100 provides in tangible terms
Strong community-building language that welcomes the donor without being transactional
Effective subtle invitation to stay connected with low-pressure framing
Good length at approximately 230 words, within the 200-300 range
Avoids making another ask and focuses purely on gratitude and impact
weaknesses: Mathematical error: states 'Your $50 provides...' then 'Your $100 puts those kits into the hands of two students' - this is confusing because the donor gave $100, not $50, making the breakdown awkward
The phrase 'Dear Friend' is generic when personalization would be expected in a real donor letter
Minor: 'steady, local change' seems slightly inconsistent for a national organization, though it could refer to local implementation
